And, or: Truth table for P∧Q and P∨Q

 

Conditional statement: If P then Q. P⇒Q

A conditional statement, often written as "If P, then Q" (or P→Q), is a fundamental concept in logic. It asserts that if the first part (the antecedent, P) is true, then the second part (the consequent, Q) must also be true.

Here's what its truth table looks like:

Tip

  1. If P is True and Q is True, then P→Q is True:

    • This is the most straightforward case. If your premise is true and your conclusion is also true, the "if-then" statement holds.

    • Example: "If it's raining (True P), then the ground is wet (True Q)." This statement is true.

  2. If P is True and Q is False, then P→Q is False:

    • This is the only scenario where a conditional statement is false. If your premise is true, but your conclusion is false, then the "if-then" relationship is broken.

    • Example: "If it's raining (True P), then the ground is dry (False Q)." This statement is false because the conclusion contradicts the premise being true.

  3. If P is False and Q is True, then P→Q is True:

    • This can sometimes be counterintuitive, but think of it this way: if the antecedent (P) doesn't happen, the conditional statement doesn't make a false claim. It's not "broken" because the condition for it to be tested (P being true) was never met.

    • Example: "If you jump off a cliff (False P), then you'll fly (True Q - in a fictional scenario where you could fly)." The statement isn't false, because you didn't jump off the cliff in the first place. Another way to think about it is: if the initial condition isn't met, the statement isn't violated, regardless of the consequent.

  4. If P is False and Q is False, then P→Q is True:

    • Similar to the previous case, if the antecedent (P) is false, the conditional statement is considered true. No claim is violated if the initial condition isn't met.

    • Example: "If the sun is made of cheese (False P), then pigs can fly (False Q)." This statement is true, because the premise ("the sun is made of cheese") is false, so the conditional statement hasn't been disproven.

 

Logical equivalence

Two statements are said to be logically equivalent if they have the same truth value in every possible scenario or for every possible combination of truth values of their component variables.

We use the symbol "三" or " ⇔ " to denote logical equivalence. Two logically equivalent statements would have identical truth tables.

For example, P⇒Q⇔(¬Q)⇒(¬p). This specific equivalence is known as the contrapositive.

Here's the truth table:

 

De Morgan's law

¬(P∧Q)=(¬P)∨(¬Q)¬(P∨Q)=(¬P)∧(¬Q)

 

Quantifiers

  • Universal quantifier ∀: For all. "For all...", "For every...", "For each...", "Given any..."

  • Existential quantifier: ∃: "there exists" or "there is a" or "for some"

Example

∀x∈R,∃y∈R s.t y3=x. This statement is true.

∃y∈R,∀x∈R,y3=X. This statement is false.

 

Negating

¬(∀x∈X,P(x))=∃x∈X,¬P(x)¬(∃x∈X,P(x))=∀x∈X,¬P(x)

¬(P⇒Q)=P∧(¬Q)

 

Proof techniques

Proof by contrapositive P⇒Q⇔¬Q⇒¬p

by contradiction P⇒Q. Start with ¬(P⇒Q)⇔P∧(Q), then try to find a contradiction.

example: Show that a∈Z, if a2 is even then a is even

Suppose a2 is even and a is odd. So. a=2b+1 for Some b∈Z then a2=(2b+1)2=4b2+4b+1⇒ odd.

biconditional P⇔Q.

statement P is true if and only if statement Q is true.

Show P⇒Q and Q⇒P separately

Mathematical induction. It is used to prove that a statement or a property P(n) is true for every natural number n∈N. starting from n=1

Tip

(Base) - prove that the statement is true for n=1 (or the first case)

(Inductive) Assume the statement is true for arbitrary k and prove that the statement is also True for (k+1)

Example

Prove ∀n∈N,(∑i=1i)=n(n+1)2 Suppose n=1, LHS: 1 RHS: 1 Suppose n=k. we have ∑i=1ki=k(k+1)2 when n=k+1∑i=1k+1=k(k+1)2+k+1=(k+1)(k2+1)=(k+1)(k+2)2

Example

proof De Morgan's law.

(1)(⋃i=1nAi)c=⋂i=1nAic

First prove: When n=2:(A1∪A2)c=A1c∩A2c

Suppose there exists x∈(A1∪A2)c⇒x∉A1∪A2

⇒x∉A1 and x⊄A2 ⇒x∈A1c and x∈A2c⇒x∈A1c∩A2c.

Then let n=k, assume we have, (⋃i=1kAi)c=⋂i=1kAic, we must show (⋃i=1k+1Ai)c=⋂i=1k+1Aic

 

Euclidean space

 

Definition: The length of a vector x=(x1,x2,…,xn)∈Rn, denoted ∥x∥, and also called the Euclidean norm of x , is given by the equation

(2)∥x∥:=x12+x22+⋯+xn2

Theorem: For all x,y∈Rn and all α∈R : (N1) ∥x∥≧0; (N2) ∥x∥=0⇔x=0; (N3) ∥αx∥=|α|∥x∥; (N4) ∥x+y∥≦∥x∥+∥y∥, the triangle inequality.

 

Definition: The dot product of two vectors x and x~ in Rn (also called the scalar product, or inner product, of x and x~ ), denoted x⋅x~, is defined as

(3)x⋅x~:=x1x~1+x2x~2+⋯+xnx~n

Note that for any vector x∈Rn, we have x⋅x=∥x∥2, and therefore x⋅x≧0 for all x∈Rn; and we have x⋅x=0 if and only if x=0.

Theorem: For all x,y,z∈Rn and all α∈R : (D1) x⋅y=y⋅x, (D2) x⋅(y+z)=x⋅y+x⋅z, (D3) (αx)⋅y=α(x⋅y), (D4) (x+y)⋅(x+y)=x⋅x+2(x⋅y)+y⋅y.

 

Theorem (The Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality): For all x,y∈Rn:|x⋅y|≦∥x∥∥y∥.

The Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality is an important link between the concepts of dot product and length.

Proof

Define the vector αx+βy, where α=∥y∥ and β=∥x∥. We have

(4)∥αx+βy∥2=(∥y∥x+∥x∥y)⋅(∥y∥x+∥x∥y)=∥y∥2x⋅x+2∥x∥∥y∥x⋅y+∥x∥2y⋅y=2∥x∥2∥y∥2+2∥x∥∥y∥x⋅y=2∥x∥∥y∥(∥x∥∥y∥+x⋅y)

Since ∥αx+βy∥2,∥x∥, and ∥y∥ are all non-negative, the above equation yields ∥x∥∥y∥+x⋅y≧0, i.e., ∥x∥∥y∥≧−x⋅y.

Now let's consider the vector αx+βy, where α=∥y∥ and β=−∥x∥. Now we have

(5)∥αx+βy∥2=(∥y∥x−∥x∥y)⋅(∥y∥x−∥x∥y)=∥y∥2x⋅x−2∥x∥∥y∥x⋅y+∥x∥2y⋅y=2∥x∥∥y∥(∥x∥∥y∥−x⋅y)

so by the same argument as above we now have ∥x∥∥y∥−x⋅y≧0, i.e., ∥x∥∥y∥≧x⋅y. We've now established that ∥x∥∥y∥≧−x⋅y and ∥x∥∥y∥≧x⋅y− i.e.,

(6)∥x∥∥y∥≧max{x⋅y,−x⋅y}=|x⋅y|,

 

Theorem (The Triangle Inequality): For all x and y in Rn:∥x+y∥≦∥x∥+∥y∥. Proof:

(7)∥x+y∥2=∥x∥2+2x⋅y+∥y∥2≦∥x∥2+2|x⋅y|+∥y∥2≦∥x∥2+2∥x∥∥y∥+∥y∥2=(∥x∥+∥y∥)2,

which, since ∥x∥+∥y∥≧0, yields ∥x+y∥≦∥x∥+∥y∥.

 

Metric space

Definition: Let X be a set. A metric on X is a function d:X×X→R+that satisfies (D1) (D4). The pair ( X,d ) is called a metric space.

Note

The distance function d:R×R to R+has the following properties: (D1) d(x,x′)≧0; (D2) d(x,x′)=0⇔x=x′; (D3) d(x,x′)=d(x′,x); (D4) d(x,x′′)≦d(x,x′)+d(x′,x′′), the triangle inequality.

 

Open sets, closed sets, interior, closure, boundary

Definition: A subset S of a metric space ( X,d ) is open if it contains an open ball about each of its points - i.e., if

(8)∀x∈S:∃ϵ>0:B(x,ϵ)⊆S

Theorem:

(O1) ∅ and X are open sets.

(O2) If S1,S2,…,Sn are open sets, then ∩i=1nSi is an open set.

(O3) Let A be an arbitrary set. If Sα is an open set for each α∈A, then ∪α∈ASα is an open set. In other words, the union of any collection of open sets is open. [Note that A can be any set, not necessarily, or even typically, a subset of X.

Proof

(O1)∅ is open because the condition (1) is vacuously satisfied: there is no x∈∅.X is open because any ball is by definition a subset of X.

(O2) Let Si be an open set for i=1,…,n, and let x∈∩i=1nSi. We must find an ϵ>0 for which B(x,ϵ)⊆∩i=1nSi. For each i there is an ϵi such that B(x,ϵi)⊆Si, because each Si is open. Let ϵ=min{ϵ1,…,ϵn}. Then 0<ϵ≦ϵi for each i; therefore B(x,ϵ)⊆B(x,ϵi)⊆Si for each i i.e., B(x,ϵ)⊆∩i=1nSi.

(O3) Let x∈∪α∈ASα; we must find an ϵ>0 for which B(x,ϵ)⊆∪α∈ASα. Since x∈∪α∈ASα, we have x∈Sα¯ for some α¯. Since Sα¯ is open, there is an ϵ>0 such that B(x,ϵ)⊆Sα¯⊆∪α∈ASα.

 

Definition: A subset S of a metric space ( X,d ) is closed if it is the complement of an open set.

Theorem: (C1)∅ and X are closed sets. (C2) If S1,S2,…,Sn are closed sets, then ∪i=1nSi is a closed set. (C3) Let A be an arbitrary set. If Sα is a closed set for each α∈A, then ∩α∈ASα is a closed set. In other words, the intersection of any collection of closed sets is closed.

Proof: (C1) follows directly from (O1). (C2) and (C3) follow from (O2) and (O3) by De Morgan's Laws.

 

Definition: A limit point of a set S in a metric space ( X,d ) is an element x¯∈X for which there is a sequence in S∖{x¯} that converges to x¯ - i.e., a sequence in S, none of whose terms is x¯, that converges to x¯. Limit points are also called accumulation points of S or cluster points of S.

Note

A limit point is also called a cluster point or accumulation point.

Tip

Remark: x¯ is a limit point of S if and only if every neighborhood of x¯ contains a point in S∖{x¯}; equivalently, if and only if every neighborhood of x¯ contains an infinite number of points in S.

 

Theorem: A set is closed if and only if it contains all its limit points.

Proof

⇒: (⇒) : Let S be a closed set, and let {xn} be a sequence in S (i.e., ∀n∈N:xn∈S ) that converges to x¯∈X. We must show that x¯∈S. Suppose not - i.e., x¯∈Sc. Since Sc is open, there is an ϵ>0 for which B(x¯,ϵ)⊆Sc. Since {xn}→x¯, let n¯ be such that n>n¯⇒d(xn,x¯)<ϵ. Then for n>n¯ we have both xn∈S and xn∈B(x¯,ϵ)⊆Sc, a contradiction.

⇐: We can prove the contrapositive statement. We wanted to show that if a set contains all its limit points, we can show instead that a set is not closed implies it does not contain all its limit points.

Suppose S is not closed, we need to show it does not contain all the limit point. Since S is not closed, so Sc is not open, therefore, ∃x¯∈Sc such that every neighborhood B(x¯,ϵ)∩(Sc)c≠∅. Now define a sequence. For every n∈N, let xn∈B(x¯,1n), so {xn}⊆S⇒x¯ is a limit point. But x¯∈Sc. So S does not contain all its limit points. ◻

 

Definition: Let G be a subset of (X,d). The interior of G, denoted int G or G∘, is the union of all open subsets of G, and the closure of G, denoted clG or G¯, is the intersection of all closed sets that contain G.

Tip

  • int G is an open set, and it is actually the largest open set of G

  • G― is a closed set, and it is actually the smallest closed set that contains G.

  • G∘⊆G⊆G¯− i.e., int G⊆G⊆clG.

Note

(9)A is open ⇔A=intAA is closed ⇔A= cl A

Definition: Let G be a subset of (X,d). The exterior of G, denoted ext G, is the interior of Gc.

Tip

The exterior of G is the union of all open sets that do not intersect G− i.e., the largest open set in Gc.

Definition: Let G be a subset of (X,d). The boundary of G, denoted bdyG, is the complement of int G∪extG−i.e.,bdyG=[intG∪extG]c.
